page.title: 17 Dialect in Weaverthorpe
page.content: The dialect is a version of the old {East Riding dialect.}The village men often use it among themselves. Some of the{old words}are still in{common} {usage}:- throng for busy, larking for playing, stoggie for wood pigeon, spuggie for sparrow, cleg for horse- fly, leg for throw, manishment for feriliser, weea for where and wer (as in where) for who. Instead of "Good morning" etc., the local greeting, used mainly by men and boys, is "Now then". {A few old customs survive:}women still give a new baby money at the first meeting, the church gates into the lych-gate are tied up during a wedding and money must be thrown to the children before they are opened, and the family mourners attend church the first Sunday after the funeral.
